Fields.DialogueText: We return to port soon.
Oui. How do you feel about having a new executive officer?
He'll surely be better than the last.
Yes, she was... I do not know how to say what she was.
I would say unfortunate. Change is always difficult, but we do what we must.
What must you do?
Breaking in a new officer is a process. Sailors nowadays are all heart and no direction. I'll whip them into shape in no time.
Is he French?
I know he's male. The rest we'll find out soon enough. In the meantime, we must keep the ship running smoothly.
Of course, Capitaine. This crew is a bit like goulash.
How so?
Someone took the leftovers and made a stew of them. Nourishing, but varied, and missing a few spices.
In the Navy, you eat what's put in front of you.
Or learn to cook yourself.

Fields.MenuText: My job is to use the resources at my disposal to ensure the meal is served.
I sprinkle in a few spices here and there.
Why cook when you can order?

Fields.DialogueText: Bland but effective, I suppose.
You don't seem like a spicy person, Capitaine.
Why, you sound like a tyrant, Capitaine.
A captain must be whatever the situation requires.
Then let's be decisive. We have Morganas on the approach.
@BATTLE
Midshipman, tell me, how do you find the Captain?
I'd try the Captain's quarters, sir. I'm headed to the galley.
... No, no, I mean the Captain's temperament.
Temperament? As in a fever? I'll bet the first mate has infected us all. That man is an animal in port. Ship's doctor is that way.
No, what I mean to say is... how would one make a good impression?
On the doctor?
No, on the Captain.
Well, why didn't you say so? Easy. Just do your job and give the Morganas hell.
Mmm. And how do you find the Belle?
She could be anywhere. Really sir, I must eat.
Hold fast, Midshipman. What is the Belle like?
She's walking towards us now, sir. Decide for yourself.
Dismissed!
Crew - there's a Morgana on the horizon. Get to your stations!
Blast, trouble already!?
@BATTLE
Good morning, Captain.
Birtwistle, did your pants assault you during the night? Was there a melee? Perhaps they attempted to choke you, but you wrestled out from under to fight another day?
What, no, um...
How, then, are your pants so wrinkled?
Oh, my! Well, I don't know, Captain. I press them. Honestly. I... I just don't know. If I may, how do you keep your pants so perfectly pressed?
Simple, Birtwistle. I've ordered them to remain unwrinkled at all times.
You ordered them?
Quite right - and what's more, I think they know I meant it. I have a commanding presence, you see.
Hmm. Yes, I see.

Fields.MenuText: Do you see?
To command you must demand respect. If you can't control your pants, how will you run this battleship?
Pants are a privilege on this ship. See to it that you don't lose yours.

Fields.DialogueText: Um, I'm afraid not.
I assure you, sir, I am most capable of performing my duties!
Aye, Captain.
Birtwistle, I'm joking. Just pulling your leg, you might say.
Bollocks! I hadn't pegged you a joker!
Jokes aside, your pants are a mess. Do try to get off on the right foot with the crew. A bit more starch, perhaps?
A - Aye, Captain.
*ALARM*
To the bridge. General quarters!
@BATTLE
Paris, meet my new executive officer, William Birtwistle.
Ahem. Pleased to meet you, ma'am.
Bonjour. Officer Birtwistle, where are you from?
Brighton, ma'am. Pleased to be onboard. My wife was 'bout to throw me back in the oggin if we didn't depart soon.
Yes, well. Stand watch on the bridge, XO. I'll join you on shortly. Dismissed.
A - Aye, Captain.
An English officer? Intéressant.
He has experience with the Royal Navy, and the Marine Nationale has secured promises that he won't be taking his orders from London. We can indulge an experiment in international cooperation, surely?
Bien sûr, Capitaine. Mais... was it just me, or did he look a bit stiff? Like he bathed in starch this morning?
An officer's bearing, I suppose.
Does he cook? How do they say, fish and chips? Hahaha, English cuisine.

Fields.MenuText: Paris, we must unite the crew. Be diplomatic when discussing... divisive topics.
We float in a sea of Morganas, and you're worried about English cuisine?
Ask Birtwistle, we've not talked hobbies. This war, you know, it seems to keep interfering with my social life.

Fields.DialogueText: Naturellement! I seek only to learn of all the world's foods.
Morganas are not the only threat to my palate, mon Capitaine.
Oui. Birtwistle and I shall have a tête-à-tête.
Hmm... We'd best sound the alarm, Captain. A Morgana approaches!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Officer Birtwistle. Tell me, do you cook?
Oh, bonjour, Paris. You startled me.
Yes, well, I can boil water for a spot of tea, but cooking? My Grace wouldn't allow it.
How unfortunate. When were you disgraced?
Oh, no - Grace, my wife. She is really quite a chef.
Que c'est beau! What does she cook?
Bangers and mash, mincemeat pie, shepherd pie. She takes pride in her homemade scones - quite a treat, I tell you.
Fantastique. You are a lucky man to eat so well.
She's frequently quick to remind me.
Then perhaps you should not forget so often.
I myself specialize in the éclair. You see, an éclair is more than just pastry. The shell should be golden-brown, with a slight crunch.
The shape - straight, with no cracks, and...
*ALARM*
Duty calls!
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Paris. Rare to find you on the forward deck.
I need not be on the deck, I feel the ship beneath my fingers.
How does she feel?
Mmm... Ready for anything.
Good. I sense danger in the air tonight.
Worse. It looks like rain.
High seas are certainly ahead of us. Don't you like water, Paris?
Non, it is so wet. This splashing across my bow is insufferable.
Well, you... are a bit bow-heavy.
Excusez-moi! Whatever do you imply, Capitaine?
Your turrets. They sit rather close to the bow.
Perhaps that is true, but a well-mannered person would not speak of it. AAAAH!
Well, that was a large wave.
I must fetch my raincoat.
A Belle who doesn't like water. Now I've seen everything.
J'en doute fort. Life is full of surprises.

Fields.MenuText: As are we. We will advance into the storm.
True, and discretion the better part of valor. We'll hold back until the weather clears.
Yes, we'll skirt the edge of the storm. Our patrols are meant to be unpredictable, but not underwater.

Fields.DialogueText: Visibility will be poor. I will give it my best, Capitaine.
I should be fine with my raincoat.
If the Morganas are looking, they will find us. We must be vigilant.
I sense a Morgana is near now.
A shame they don't make coats for those.
@BATTLE
Oh, but they do. They call it armor!
Birts, how do you find the ship?
Birt-WISTLE, Captain. Our armor is a bit light compared to, say, an English ship, but we'll make do.
Excusez-moi! Light?
Certainly. Take the Orion class - the waterline belt amor is over three hundred millimeters thick.
Yes, Orion's belt is large and crude. My belt is svelte and worn fashionably low. You plan for us to be target practice, hmm?
Of course not. I only meant...
That will do, Birts. Dismissed.
Scandaleux! What nerve.
Just nationalistic pride, Paris. Do not take it personally.
He speaks of my belt! How else should I take it?

Fields.MenuText: Like the poised, intelligent Frenchwoman I know.
Do all Belles squabble with their captains' officers?
Clearly, Paris, Birtwistle is not a man of fashion.

Fields.DialogueText: Resorting to flattery, Capitaine?
Non, only the best.
Oui. He has no knowledge of haute couture.
Ah! Capitaine! A Morgana approaches.
Time to demonstrate how a svelte lady of the Marine Nationale maneuvers.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Paris. How are you and Birtwistle getting along?
Bien. Did you know his wife cooks?

Fields.MenuText: Yes. We exchange recipes over the wire. Occasionally by pigeon.
I'm not Sherlock Holmes, but he is a certainly a... solid man.
Fascinating. Perhaps she could host the Morganas and we can settle this over tea and crumpets.

Fields.DialogueText: Cooking is my heart, Capitaine.
I was not accusing you of genius, Capitaine.
Tea with Starvation?
Be serious. These wars threaten not just my people, but our culture, even our viniculture!
In the Great War, my sister Jean's wine store was torpedoed near the Bay of Vlorë. Can you imagine? That didn't stop her from steaming to Malta, mind you - and by herself too!
How many of you are there?
Courbet, France, and Jean Bart. You would do well to remember - history has been settled over the dinner table more than once.
What might be accomplished if our leaders sat for a civilized discourse? Perhaps served chocolate fondant with piment d'espelette, and a nice port...
My apologies, Paris. I only meant to lighten the mood.
Yes, well. You should apologize to the ocean.
To the ocean? Have I offended her as well?
She's quite fond of me, you know. She's feels I must be taken seriously. Trust me, you don't want to make her angry.
I see.
Well? I'm waiting...
... Ocean, I apologize.
She accepts your apology, and expects better of you in the future. Also, she tells me a Morgana is just over the horizon.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! You must address this insult!
Has XO Birtwistle struck again, or...?
The waves have made a ruin of our galley! And the crew did nothing to stop it! It seems they cannot stop from bickering amongst themselves. Rien de tout!
Breathe, Paris. I suspect the crew's focus was on the incoming rounds of Morgana artillery.
That is no excuse, Capitaine. How will you punish them?

Fields.MenuText: Cleaning the mess will be punishment enough.
Training is the answer. The chief cook will restore order and drill the crew on proper procedure to secure the galley.
This is war, Paris. We must focus on the big picture.

Fields.DialogueText: Remind the crew that not all mistakes can be cleaned up afterwards.
I suppose that will do.
My point exactly, Capitaine.
Okay. I'll look into it.
I appreciate it, Capitaine.
Although I'll have you know I'm not one to play favorites.
And I'm not one to abuse such a thing.
Good. Just as long as we're on the same page.
I feel I may be a little further ahead in the book than you are, Capitaine, but I agree. You haven't even gotten to the terrifying Morgana plot twist yet.
The wha--
*ALARM*
Shall we?
@BATTLE
What do you know of the Morganas, Captain?
Not much more than you do, I'd think. The first documented appearance was in the Bay of Gdansk just after the Germans launched their attack.
If only that were the case.
Indeed. Since emerging from the mists, they've been harassing shipments and wreaking havoc. And they're certainly not above raiding port cities when they can get away with it.
Oh, dear. They... haven't struck Brighton, have they, Captain? I was serving in the Mediterranean before transferring here, and... well, news always seemed very slow in arriving.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, I'm sure Grace is fine.
Not to my knowledge - but their attacks seem quite random.
Not yet. But if you and Grace have any family away from the coast, you might want to have a talk about her taking a bit of a vacation.

Fields.DialogueText: I certainly hope so.
Understood, Captain. Unfortunately.
Thank you, Captain. I won't deny I've thought about it.
Thanks to Paris and her peers, we seem to prove their equal. We've run off a number already. Without the Belles, our first attempts at mounting a defense were... costly.
Yes, I recall the early news reports - rather grim.
And, of course, there's the question of how many of them there are. And whether they really don't stay dead when sunk. And who built them and where their bases are, if they have bases at all...
Captain? Paris is...
Je suis ici. And, Capitaine - Morganas approach.
Well, then, Birtwistle - a chance for you to learn firsthand.
Let's teach them a thing or two!
@BATTLE
By the end of the day, though, it was pretty clear that they were active globally.
Even if half the world did initially mistake the mists for some sort of freak meteorological event.
Report, XO.
Engineering reports engine vibrations.
Oui, turbine trois.
Yes, engine three. Also, a dustup on first watch. Started as a disagreement on procedure, then the German mate spoke on the heritage of the Italian's father...
His mother.
Yes, well, regardless of the parent, the outcome...
Right.

Fields.MenuText: Birtwistle, I leave this in your hands. Do not be soft on them. They need to know that this can't continue.
Order the combatants to scrub the deck, together, from bow to stern. A single cross word and they start over.
Inform the crew that flogging has been reinstated. Infighting will not be tolerated.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye, Captain. I'll do my best.
I'll see to it.
Blimey! Flogging? Can you do that?
Dismissed, XO.
Mon Capitaine, perhaps you are too harsh.
This is war, Paris. The crew must be disciplined.
Captain, a nearby transport has sighted a Morgana vessel.
Identify their position and set a course to intercept.
@BATTLE
No, but I know a Belle or two who wouldn't mind courting a reprimand.
Report, XO.
Engineering reports successful engine repairs. We should be able to make at least 20 knots. Seas are calm.
Good news, Birts. Yet you seem troubled. What's on your mind?

War. Invasion. Does our current arrangement preclude German troop transports carrying Jerry to Dover? After the Great War, you'd think we'd never have to worry about this kind of madness again, but...
Natural to think of your countrymen, Birts, but our mission is larger than nations. We must focus on the Morganas.
Of course, Captain, but can we really expect a crew of nations at war to work together in close quarters?

Fields.MenuText: Remind the crew that on this ship, we are all enemies of the Morganas.
Keep the crew busy. Double the watches, schedule additional maintenance, and run drills regularly.
You might remind the crew that the mail censorship policy could be tightened dramatically if they get out of line.

Fields.DialogueText: As you wish, Captain. I hope that does the trick.
Aye, Captain. You know best.
As you wish, Captain. Just know that emotions run high.
See to it, Birts. When the seas are safe again, we can worry about where the flags fly.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You're still having problems?
No, discipline is holding. But the Continental sailors are tense - and as long as people can still get mail from home, there's always the risk of the land war coming to us.
Paris, I've thought on what you said.
Oui? Bien. You now understand the importance of a well-maintained galley?
Well, I understand your point of view on that, but I refer to the infighting amongst the crew.
Oh.
I don't mean to be heavy-handed. It's just that I'm running out of ideas. Birtwistle seems at the end of his chain also. We've never had such a diverse crew.
Oui. These sorts of problems do not occur in the Marine Nationale.

Fields.MenuText: Well, the crew's already closing in on 30% non-French, and guidelines say it can get up to 40% if needed. We need to find a way to make it work.
It's just a shame that the Marine Nationale didn't singlehandedly expel the Morganas from our waters.
We need the same unity with the crew we have now.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, I understand the problem, Capitaine.
I meant no offense, Capitaine.
Oui - you are right, of course.
We're not going to fail this crew, Paris - I promise you that. But the sooner we find an answer, the better it'll be.
D'accord, Capitaine. We shall find a solution. Je vais y penser.
Thank you, Paris.
I'm happy to assist. Still, it looks like another problem is coming our way... in Morgana shape.
@BATTLE
Just on a personal level, this would be a hell of a lot harder without you.
They're not at each other's throats, and heaven knows we're giving them all the language training we can, but they're all just so wary of each other.
Paris. I've been looking for you.
Quelle chance! I am here. You should always look first in the galley.
Yes, well, let us talk. You really must not make me look bad in front of the Captain.
I believe you did that yourself. You dress yourself, non?
I'm serious, Paris!
Officer Birtwistle, I'm a Courbet-class battleship. I'm built for war, not to stand behind you and look pretty.
Of course, that's not what I meant. Although - weren't you a school ship at one point?
A girl must refit now and again, but I will have you know I'm quite modern. Now what on earth do you want?
I only wonder - can you serve the Captain with me instead of over me?
What, so the Capitaine will like you better?
Of course. I hope to captain a ship myself some day, and I will need a strong recommendation.
Je vois. And what will you do for me?
What... do you want?
Hmm. I think I would like Grace's favorite recipe...
Oh, is that all? Of course. Thank you, Paris - you shall have it.
And going back to what you said earlier - just what is wrong with my uniform?
Everything. To start, your legs billow like two rolling pins. Use less starch and perhaps relax a little.
Too much starch?!
Oui. A Morgana approaches. Can you attend to your station or does that also require explanation?
@BATTLE
This shoreline reminds me of my summers at Corfu. So beautiful. And the people - so friendly!
Did you hear that? Capitaine, that bird sings for you.
The seagull?
Yes. Oh, how fortunate. It speaks French.
What does it say?
A strong accent, but I believe... "rare to find such an enchanting lady on the high seas."
Indeed?
Oui! She goes on: "Why was that beast allowed on board? Or am I seeing a stowaway?"
Oh, she refers to you, Capitaine. She says "How fortunate the beast is to be instructed by a cultured French gourmand."
We anticipated threats from the air. That's why you were outfitted with Hotchkiss machine guns. In fact, now would be an excellent time for an air defense drill.
I'm afraid she's just out of range, Capitaine.
We'll adjust course.
*ALARM*
How fortunate.
@BATTLE
You wouldn't really have shot that bird, would you?

Fields.MenuText: Naturally. It was too far away for swordplay.
Of course not. I'd order someone else to shoot it.
Now you'll never know.

Fields.DialogueText: The bird was right - you are a beast!
The burden of command.
Oui. Vous êtes un mystère, Capitaine.
Birts. What news?
The forward three hundred and five millimeter turret is inoperable. Engineering is working on it.
Oui - as you explained to me earlier, the projectile hoist is misaligned with the spanning tray.
Uh, quite right, Paris. That seems to be the primary issue.
Well, your attention to detail is commendable, Birts. A good officer knows his ship backwards and forwards. Supervise the repairs - we need all guns operational.
Aye, Captain!
The XO seems to be finding his way, Capitaine.
He does seem to know his job.
His wife Grace surprises me with her ingenuity. During a meat shortage, she served a vegetable sausage over a parsnip apple mash. Can you imagine?
Yes, well, I suppose we all have our battles to fight.
Capitaine, the sonar operator reports contact.
I should watch my mouth.
The ocean agrees. She says it's a Morgana, bearing twenty-three degrees to port.
@BATTLE
Hello, Paris. Sorry to bother you in your quarters. Thank you for - ahem - assisting me in my report to the Captain. Quite generous of you.
Oui, well, we're all on the same side, non? Thank you for Grace's recipe. You must send my compliments.
I will, and I'm sure she'll be quite pleased. Is that wine?
Join me for a glass?
Ah, don't mind if I do. Say, Is that a case of port under your bunk?
Perhaps.
Oh, don't worry, ma'am. I've been known to stow some wayward bottles in my bunk for safekeeping.
Your secret is safe with me. What's happened to your tie?
My tie, ma'am?
Oui. Was it attacked by a boa constrictor? I don't think the Capitaine allows pets.
I've no pets, ma'am. What is wrong with my tie?
It's far too tight. Let it breathe a little.
Yes, well, I'll see to it. I'd best be heading back before I start listing to port.
Salut, Birtie!
Birts!
Aye. Paris was just, um, advising me on my difficulties with my uniform sir.

Fields.MenuText: Certainly someone should.
Were you having difficulty getting it back on?
I do hope to see some improvements soon.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I'll visit a tailor in port.
No sir, nothing like that! Our relationship is strictly professional.
Aye, Captain!
Pressing as this matter is, we've got a bigger problem on our hands...
@BATTLE
Capitaine, look there. The mist.
It never fails to give me the shivers.
Yes, the edges of the mist are cold. Inside visibility is very poor. We would be wise not to enter.
The last time we got too close, our gauges went nuts.
The mists tend to disrupt electronics.
Ensign, adjust our course to maintain our current distance from the mist.
Aye, Captain.
Radioman, report back to the fleet our current position and the presence of the mist.
The instruments are acting up, Captain.
Ensign, estimate our position based on our last position. Radioman, take his mark and get the word out.
Oui, Capitaine!
I feel something. There! A ship emerges from the mist, Capitaine.
Battle stations!
Helmsman, full speed away from the pea soup. If we can engage the thing outside the mist, our odds get a lot better.
Aye, Captain. Full speed.
@BATTLE
*Ahem* I didn't realize you were giving the orders, Birtwistle.
Forgive me, Capitaine, I should not have overstepped. I wish to be of your rank some day myself and I was simply practicing.
A fine dream, but do not let it happen again. As for the order... what he said.
Paris, you seem distracted.
Not distracted. Thinking.
Sounds dangerous.
The ship and crew have performed admirably, given these less than ideal circumstances.
But...?
I feel there may be an opportunity to... further unite the crew.
I see. How might that be?
Well, our galley is, how to say... so basic. Perhaps if we stocked it more creatively, the crew could experience the cuisine of all of their nations.
Paris, are you telling me you can cook the crew together?
French battleships are held together by more than steel, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Have you discussed this with the chief cook?
Paris, are you concussed? I think you'd better report immediately to the ship's doctor.
I see. Well, we must realize our potential.

Fields.DialogueText: The ordinary must not stand in the way of the possible.
I assure you I'm quite well.
Merci beaucoup, Capitaine!
We'll try it your way, Paris. Prepare a list of necessary supplies. I will inform the chief cook of our special project.
There are things even the Royal Naval College can't prepare you for.
Captain, a ship on the horizon!
General quarters!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I'm giddy, I can hardly wait.
Wait? For what?
Tomorrow is the Concours de Cuisine.
A contest of food?
Yes. Each watch will dine on the food of our host nations, voting for their favorite dishes. The winners will become part of our ship's tradition, served after victories.

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe I've agreed to this.
Tomorrow then, we'll have a one-time extension of meal times so the crew may carefully consider their votes.
Is it too late to cancel this?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, a rare moment of wisdom for you.
Bien! I'm glad you're embracing the contest.
Not unless you want to swim home.
Well, I suppose the crew does deserve some recreation.
Oui. Wait and see, Capitaine. It will be fantastique!
I appear to have no choice.
*ALARM*
Time to earn our supper.
@BATTLE
Congratulations, Paris. The contest is a great success.
Aye, Captain. First time I've seen some of these men really talk. They're discussing their votes and talking up their country's food. Which is all delicious.
Merci beaucoup.
Paris, honestly, when you told me about this event, I thought the most it would do was make the crew more comfortable with *you.*
Merci, Capitaine. You can learn much from simple culinary culture.
Indeed. I believe a little bird once told me so.
Perhaps now you will not be so quick to question my advice.
Let's not go overboard, Paris.
What? Why would I jump into the water? I will not, Capitaine, with you, or with anyone.
It's just an expression, Paris. I know how you feel about water.
A ridiculous expression.
What's that on the gramophone?
Cole Porter, from my collection. The song is "I've Got You Under My Skin."

Fields.MenuText: Shall we dance, then?
Fitting. This crew has you under their skin.
What a racket.

Fields.DialogueText: Now?
But not you, Capitaine?
Just when I thought you might be developing taste.
*ALARM*
Damn! The Morganas take this from us too.
Secure the galley. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
But you've succeeded in uniting this crew over croissants and spritzkuchen - or at least breaking the ice. I salute you.
There's music on and I'm not the best whistler.
Tell me, Captain. What did happen to my predecessor?

Fields.MenuText: Really none of your business, Birts.
I suppose you should know.
Paris, should we tell him?

Fields.DialogueText: It's part of my history. If you don't tell him, I will.
I'm sure we can count on his discretion.
Birtie's earned the right to know.
Yes, well, it was a case of battle fatigue. At first just a few quirks, an odd remark here and there.
Then there was the incident.
An incident?
Yes, I really don't like to speak of it.
Finish the story, Capitaine.
Yes, well. We were in combat with enemy battleships when she disappeared. I was about to send a search party when she... well, she...
She ran across the deck, wearing the ship's flag, yelling "Vive la France!"
Oh, dear.
Yes, we had to lock her in her quarters until we reached port.
Her heart was in the right place, but her mind was somewhere else.
Happily, she seems to have made a full recovery. The Neutrality Fleet determined her best use is now with fleet administration.
That seems prudent.
History class is over - we have an approaching Morgana.
Keep that story to yourself, Birts, and leave the flag on the mast.
Quite right, Captain.
@BATTLE
Capitaine. A word?
Do come in. Paris and I were just about to call on you, in fact.
Is that so?
Seeing as you're here, I'll skip the pleasantries and get right down to brass tacks. How have you been finding your new position?
Other than a few teething issues, I have done my best to adhere to your standards.

Fields.MenuText: What would you rate your job performance?

Fields.DialogueText: Full marks for effort and perhaps a few off for execution. I am nothing if not humble.

Fields.MenuText: Do you still hold dreams of leading your own ship one day?

Fields.DialogueText: Very much so. I am nothing without my convictions.

Fields.MenuText: Paris, what do you think of Birtwistle's performance?

Fields.DialogueText: It sounds like you want me to do your job for you.
Well, I suppose there is only one thing left to say.
Please.
Welcome aboard, Birtwistle. I look forward to our continued partnership.
*Exhale* As am I.
Now, why are you still standing here?!
Of course!
Honestly, Capitaine, you should leave the torturing to me.
He'll make a fine addition to our crew, don't you think?
*ALARM*
That depends on how many Morganas he can take out. With me, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
Where are you from, Paris?
My stomach, Bouillon Chartier. My eyes, Odéon, and my heart, it beats in the cellars of Bercy.
Hahaha! That was not the answer I was expecting...
What of you, Capitaine?
I am of the sea, Paris. Salt water runs through my veins, my teeth are pearl, and the ocean's undertow pulses through my heart.
Hahaha! What do those of the sea eat?
On a good day, fish. Or shrimp.
On a bad day?
Kelp. On the worst day, algae. What do you eat, Paris?
An important question. For each meal I must consider the mood, the company, the moment.
Say then... right now, here with me.
For you, perhaps Moules Marinières, a bottle of Sancerre Domaine de la Perrière with Crottin de Chavignol, and for dessert, clafoutis.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds complicated.
I'd rather have steak with potatoes.
Sounds delicious.

Fields.DialogueText: For a complex person, you have a simple stomach.
A chacun son goût! There is no accounting for taste.
A Votre Santé! To eat well is to live right.
*ALARM*
Now, I hunger for victory.
l'Arrivé!
@BATTLE
Bonjour. What do you see in the waves, Paris?
Water, Capitaine. It surrounds us.
Yes. That is the nature of the ocean. Across the world, war wages, and yet the waves roll peacefully.
The calm before the storm.
Perhaps.
What of you, Capitaine? Are you calm?
Is there a reason not to be?
Now that Birtwistle has joined us, I would have hoped it would free up your mind a little.
Well, it is certainly true that I will be keeping less of a keen eye on Birtwistle.
I see. And where will this aforementioned keen eye be travelling to next?

Fields.MenuText: I will keep tabs on the crew and the horizon ahead, of course. I hope you will join me.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course. I will help to lighten the load in any way I can. To the horizon, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: Seeing as you keep tabs on the crew well enough, I suppose I'll focus on you.

Fields.DialogueText: Me? I don't know what you intend to find by monitoring me, Capitaine.
Neither do I. But I'm looking forward to finding out.
